awd_titl_txt: Infinite dimensional variational problems and their dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
In optimal transportation theory, one looks for the best strategies to transport, say, a pile of dirt, to an excavation, where optimality is measured against a prescribed cost function. In his earlier research, the principal investigator (PI) created new tools for optimal transport theory, a theory which  has experienced a mathematical renaissance over the last twenty-five years by weaving together threads from analysis, geometry, partial differential equations (PDEs) and dynamical systems. Motivated by his work on systems with large numbers of particles, the PI, with collaborators,  has discovered some connections between optimal transportation, games with a large number of players, and Mean Field Games. These unexpected connections open doors to several new  avenues of research, some of which being  described in this proposal.  The goal of this project is to advance knowledge in various other related topics. This includes the geometry of the space of closed differential forms with  the  non--linear factorization of  differential forms.  This proposal involves  training students, mentoring postdocs and organizing  learning seminars for graduate students. The PI will remain involved in national as well as international activities. These, constitute the broader impacts of the proposed activities. 

The PI studies the mathematical aspects of Density Functional Theory (DFT), as well as  certain  geometric clustering problems originating in combinatorial optimization. What many of these problems have in common, and what is sometimes novel in the approach for studying them, is their formulation on infinite dimensional ``manifolds''  equipped with metric, differential, and symplectic pseudo-structures.  This infinite dimensional setting often lead to a new outlook and --at least on the formal level-- to novel and simpler approaches to otherwise complex problems. A typical example is how Otto's calculus turns many nonlinear PDEs into gradient flows of geodesically convex functionals. In a similar fashion, our searching for geodesic of minimal lengths on the set of  differential forms, leads to a new concept of ``quasiconvexity," that looks like an extension of the concept originally  introduced by C. Morrey and used extensively in non--linear elasticity theory. Part of the challenge, however, includes turning formal arguments into rigorous ones to yield new results.  The intellectual merit of the research is that the problems to be studied have the potential of revealing principles which can be extended to a more general context.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL NERIT

This project was a great contribution to the Mean Field Games theory. A substantial progress has been made on games with Hamiltonians which are not necessarily separable. Our success is due to the identification of a new concept of monotonicity condition which we termed displacement monotonicity. 

This project also studied of Hamiltonian systems involving infinitely many particles. It helped  understand convergence properties of finite particles systems to infinite particles  systems. We proved a general result on finite dimensional approximations, with common noise convergence of Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman in the space of probability measures. We prove uniform continuity estimates  for the viscosity solution of the approximate problem. This work was selected to be presented at the February 2021 SIAM PDE webinar, and we learned from SIMA that  it was deemed among the best articles accepted by SIMA. 

Direct  methods of the calculus of variations has been extended from the set of volume forms to the set of 2-form with the extension of Morrey's quasiconvexity condition.

EDUCATION

The project also carried a good educational component. During Summer 2020, the PI supervised the research of  sophomore undergraduate student Mr. Wang. Mr. Wang wrote an impressive report on optimal transportation theory, to make it accessible to undergrad students with no measure theory background. This report was selected to be presented at UCLA's virtual Undergraduate Research Creativity Show Case in 2021. During summer 2021, the mentored Ms. Peart a junior undergrad student of Villanova University. He strengthened her background in Real Analysis and gave her a problem at the frontier of Real Analysis and Algebra. Shaniya will join the Duke Mathematics PhD program in Fall 2022. The same summer, the PI  mentored the summer research of Ms. Pham, an undergrad junior student of the University of Minnesota. She was later among the students selected by the organizers of the 2021 Young Mathematicians Conference, to present her summer work. Nhung will join the Yale Mathematics PhD program in Fall 2022. 

BROADER IMPACTS

The broader impacts of this project concerned undergraduate, graduate and postdocs. For instance,iIn collaboration with Profs. J. Nelson (UC Berkeley) and T. Coleman (Stanford), the PI launched the David Blackwell Summer Research Institute in 2021. This is a six weeks elite research program for undergraduate students, which aims to honor Blackwell's legacy by attempting to increase the number of  students who aspire to achieve his level of excellence and widen participation of URM groups.All the rising seniors of the first cohort were female who in 2022, enrolled in PhD programs at respectively: Yale University, Duke University and a new Interdisciplinary Media and Design program at Northeastern University. 

The PI mentored a total of seven postdocs. (i) A. Meszaros (2016--2019, tenure--track position at Durham University, UK). (ii)  C. Mou (2016--2020, tenure--track position at the Chinese University of Hong--Kong). (iii)  K. Nam (2020--2021, tenure--track position at KAIST, South Korea). (iv) Jointly co--mentored postdoc M. Jacobs (2020--2021, tenure--track position at Purdue University).  (v) WG is currently mentoring L. Nuberkeyan (2019-2023); K. Enakoutsa (2020--2023) and A. Palmer (2021--2024).


Last Modified: 10/03/2022
Modified by: Wilfrid Gangbo
